moves.1. e4: This was a case of what David Bronstein calls "milking a cow": I obtained a small advantage and then gradually turned the screws until my advantages became overwhelming, culminating in checkmate.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Qf6: Already, Black is at a positional disadvantage. Way too early to move the Queen.
moves.4... Bb4 5. Qd2 exd4 6. Qxd4: I will end up with a central advantage and a plus in development.
moves.6... Bxc3+ 7. bxc3 Qxd4 8. cxd4 d6: Black's opening has been very weak. All I have to do is begin tightening the screws.
My Rook will soon take over the e-file, while Black's development is badly lagging.
moves.13... Nd7 14. Re1 Ngf6 15. f3: The pin is mightier than the sword. Black has no way to avoid losing the Bishop. If Black had been able to castle more quickly, his Bishop wouldn't have been exposed to the pin.
moves.15... Rc8 16. Bb5: Now two of Black's pieces are pinned. Resignation wouldn't be a bad choice.
moves.17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Rxe4: Now it's a matter of technique. I'm a piece up in what is essentially already an endgame.
moves.18... Ne5 19. Nb5 Rxc2 20. Nxd6 Nd3: Black must press forward. Passive play = certain defeat.
moves.21. Bf4 Nf2 22. Rc4: Either Black submits to the exchange of Rooks or he loses more material.
With Black being forced to retreat his Knight, his drawing chances vanish.
moves.25... b5 26. Ne5 Rxd6 27. Rxd3: The exchange of minor pieces only helps me.
moves.27... a5 28. Nc6 a4 29. a3: Black's Queen-side Pawns are now frozen and primed to fall.
moves.29... b4 30. Nxb4: Now I have to move Black's Rook out of the way to advance my passed Pawn.
moves.30... h5 31. Na2 f5 32. Nc3 g5 33. g3 h4: After some time-wasting on the King-side, I put my plan into action.
moves.38... Rd7 39. d6 Rd8 40. d7: I was shocked when Black didn't resign here. He wants to play it out to the mate.
